choices.text: Extension at hip joint, flexion at knee joint
Flexion at hip joint, extension at knee joint
Flexion at both hip and knee joint
Extension at both hip and knee joint

questions.text: A 30yr primi is diagnosed with Frank breech. Which statement is true about frank breech?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Flexion at hip joint, extension at knee joint

 

In a Frank Breech, there is flexion at the hip joint and extension at the knee joint

 

Educational Objective: 

 

 

  • Extended Breech (Frank breech): Flexion at hip joint, Extension at knee joint
  • Flexed Breech (Complete breech): Flexion at hip joint, flexion at knee joint
  • Footling breech: Extension at hip and knee joint
  • Kneeling breech: Extension at hip joint, flexion at knee joint 

 

Ref: Page no 322 JB Sharma Textbook of Obstetrics 3rd edition

choices.text: Commence an infusion of oxytocin
Improve maternal hydration with intravenous fluids
Observe for a further period of 1 hour for spontaneous delivery to occur
Perform a lower segment cesarean section

questions.text: A primigravida with a breech presentation is in the second stage of labor for 2 hours. The fetal heart rate is 140 beats per minute. She is getting 3 uterine contractions per 10 minutes. The breech is felt at the level of the ischial spines. The membranes are absent. The estimated fetal weight is 3 kg. What is the most appropriate management?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Perform a lower segment cesarean section

  • In the question patient is a primigravida
  • She is in 2nd stage of labor for 2 hours with breech, i.e. it is a case of prolonged second stage of labor. 
  • In prolonged second stage, it is not advisable to rupture membranes due to the risk of cord prolapse and not by oxytocin because strong contractions produced by oxytocin can cause descent of soft breech even, if there is fetopelvic disproportion with resultant difficulty in delivery of fetal head.
  • In case of breech, delay in 1st or 2nd stage is regarded as a sign of fetopelvic disproportion and requires cesarean section.

Other options:

  • Option A: Commence an infuion of oxytocin: This will not helo in progress of labor as she is already getting good uterine contractions.
  • Option B: Improve maternal hydration with intravenous fluids: Alhtough this will generally help improve the maternal and fetal condition, it is unlikely to help in progress of labor as the likely cause is feto-pelvoc disproportion
  • Option C: Observe for a further period of 1 hour for spontaneous delivery to occur: This wil not help either.

Educational Objective:

  • Primi breech (at term) is usually an indication for immediate cesarean section 
  • If the labor is unduly prolinged in breech (in the presence of strong uterine contractions), cesarean is the better option as there may be feto-pelvic disproportion

Ref: Page no 329  JB Sharma Textbook of Obstetrics 3rd edition.

choices.text: Await spontaneous onset of labor and normal vaginal delivery
Perform a cesarean section at 39 weeks
Perform a cesarean section, if labor becomes prolonged
Perform an external cephalic version

questions.text: A 40yr primi presents to the antenatal clinic at 38 weeks. On examination, the fetus is in breech presentation. The estimated fetal weight is 3 kg. On pelvic examination, the cervix is closed, 3 cm long, soft and posterior. The breech is high up. The pelvis appears adequate. The best management option is?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Perform cesarean section at 39 weeks.

 

  • The best answer would be to perform a cesarean at 39 weeks as she is not very favourable for an assisted breech delivery. Rememebr primi brrech is usually a direct indication for a cesarean section. 

 

 

  • In this patient as points against a successful delivery are:
    • Primi
    • Poor Bishop score
    • High station

Inclusion Criteria for Planned Vaginal Breech Delivery:

 

  • Gestational age ≥ 37 weeks
  • Frank or complete breech presentation
  • No fetal anomalies
  • Adequate maternal pelvis
  • Estimated fetal weight between 2,500–4,000 g
  • Normal amniotic fluid volume (≥3 cm vertical pocket)
  • Documented flexed fetal head
  • No contraindication to vaginal birth
  • Continuous fetal monitoring must be available

 

Contraindications to Vaginal Breech Delivery:

 

  • Footling breech
  • Hyperextended fetal head
  • Inadequate pelvis
  • Estimated fetal weight <2,500 g or >4,000 g
  • Suspected fetal compromise or anomalies

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Await spontaneous onset of labor and normal vaginal delivery: A cesarean delivery would be more favourable for this patient as there is a high chance of the aftercoming head of breech getting stuck in this patient.

 

Option C. Perform a cesarean if labor is prolonged: An elective cesarean is better in this patient as she is not favourable for an assisted breech delivery. 

 

Option D. Perform an external cephalic version: External cephalic version is best attempted at 36-37 weeks and shpuld not be done now at 39 weeks as the failure rate is higher and it is more difficult to do. 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • This is the Zatuchni Andros Score for breech delivery. A score of 3 or less, cesarean is preferred

 

 

Ref: Page no 329  JB Sharma Textbook of Obstetrics 3rd edition

choices.text: Lovset’s method
Smellie-Veit
Pinard’s maneuver
Ritgen's maneuver

questions.text: Best method to deliver nuchal arms in breech?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Lovset’s method

 

Lovsets manuever is used in delivery of nuchal arms while conducting an assisted breech delivery. 

 

Other Options

 

  • Option B: Smellie-Viet: This maneuver is used to deliver the aftercoming head in a breech delivery
  • Option C: Pinard maneuver: This is used to deliver the legs expecially in a total breech extraction
  • Option D: Ritgen's maneuver: This maneuver is used in cephalic presentation and is controleld extension of the head int he 2nd stage of laboe

 

Educational Objective:

 

Assisted Breech Delivery:

 

  • In breech delivery assistance may be required for:
  1. Delivery of head 
    •  Burns-Marshall method
    • Mauriceau-Smellie-Veit method
    • Piper’s forceps or Neville-Barnes forceps
       
  2. Extended legs 
    • Pinard’s maneuver (Remember: P for popliteal fossa and P for Pinard maneuver)
  3. Extended arm
  • Lovset’s maneuver

 

Sometimes the head rotates posteriorly, so that the face is behind the pubis. Delivery in this position is difficult and ‘Prague maneuver’ may be tried.

  • Best time for episiotomy in breech
    Climbing of perineum.
  • Best time for episiotomy in vertex
    Crowning of head.

 

Ref: Page no 329  JB Sharma Textbook of Obstetrics 3rd edition.

choices.text: External cephalic version
Induction of labor at 38 weeks
Elective LSCS
NST

questions.text: A 34 yr G2P1 unbooked patient with a previous normal delivery presents to the OPD at 37 weeks. On examination, you find that the uterus is term size and the breech is occupying the lower pole of the uterus. What is the next best step?
questions.solution:
Ans.  A. External cephalic version

  • This patient is a multigravida with breech presentation at 37 weeks
  • Ideally, breech should be confirmed by ultrasound. This will also help look for possible causes of breech like multiple pregnancy, placenta previa, fetal anomalie, oligo or polyhydramnios and also help look for possible contra-indications to ECV like a hyper-extended head (Star-gazing fetus)
  • As she is 37 weeks, External cephalic version (ECV) can be done

Let's discuss the other options

  • Option B: Induction of labor at 38 weeks: Even if a vaginal breech delivery is planned for this patient, there is no indication for induction at 38 weeks of labor. 
  • Option C: Elective cesarean section: This is a possible option but when a patient with breech who has otherwise no complications and is between 36-37 weeks, an external cephalic version should always be offered to her. 
  • Option D: NST: Although this is an integral part of antepartum fetal surveillance, it is not the next best step

 

Educational Objective:

  • ECV is an external maneuver to turn the baby from breech (or transverse lie) to cephalic presentation.
  • ECV is ideally done at 36-37 weeks
  • IT reduces the incidence of cesarean sections
  • Absolute contra-indications do during an ECV are:
    • Placenta Previa
    • Contracted Pelvis
    • Multiple Pregnancy
    • Hyperextended head
    • Anomaly
    • Dead fetus
    •  Distressed fetus
    •  Denied consent.
  • A previous scar on the uterus (like a previous cesarean) is a relative contra-indication
  • Factors favoring an ECV are:
    • Multiparity
    • Non engaged presenting part
    • Adequate liquor
    • Non-Anterior placenta
  • Factors associated with failure of ECV are:
    • Nulliparity
    • Extended breech
    • Anterior placenta
    • Liquor more or less
    • Maternal obesity
    • Posterior spine
    • Short cord
    • Breech in the pelvis
  • Complications of an ECV are:
    • Fetal distress
    • Abruption
    • PROM
    • Rupture uterus
    • AFE
    • Rh isoimmunization (in Rh incompatible couples)

 

 

Ref: Page no 737  JB Sharma Textbook of Obstetrics 3rd edition

choices.text: Burns-Marshall method
Forceps delivery
Modified Mauriceau-Smellie-Veit technique
Lovset’s maneuver

questions.text: Techniques of delivery of after-coming head in breech presentation are all except?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Lovset's maneuver

Methods of delivery after-coming head of breech:

  • Burns-Marshall technique (Option A)
  • Mauriceau-Smellie-Veit technique (Option C)
  • Piper’s forcep or Neville Barnes forceps (Option B)

Lovset’s method is used for delivery of extended arms in breech.

Educational Objective:

Methods of delivery after-coming head of breech:

  • Burns-Marshall technique 
  • Mauriceau-Smellie-Veit technique 
  • Piper’s forcep or Neville Barnes forceps 

 

 

 

 

Ref: Page no 329  JB Sharma Textbook of Obstetrics 3rd edition

choices.text: 1,2,3
2,3,4
3,4,5
2,3,5

questions.text: Which are correct statements about Breech delivery?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. 2,3,5

Let's Discuss all the choices

  • Option 1: Vasa previa is a complication: This is incorrect. “Vasa previa occurs when the fetal blood vessel (s) from the placenta or umbilical cord cross the entrance to the birth canal, beneath the baby. Vasa previa can result in rapid fetal hemorrhage (occurs from the vessels tearing when the cervix dilates or membrane rupture) or lack of oxygen (If the vessels become pinched off as they are compressed between the baby and the walls of the birth canal). The aberrant vessels result from velamentous insertion of the cord, bilobed or succenturiate lobed placenta”.
  • Option 2: Fetal congenital malformation increases the risk of breech presentation: This is Correct. Several malformations like hydrocephalus and anencephaly increase the incidence of breech presentation
  • Option 3: There is increased fetal and maternal morbidity: This is correct. Because of increased frequency of operative delivery including cesarean section, the maternal morbidity is increased. Fetal injury is also increased. Fetal risk in terms of perinatal mortality is considerable in vaginal breech delivery.
  • Option 4: Oligohydramnios decreases the risk of breech. This is incorrect as oligohydramnios increases the risk of breech. Babies who would have turned otherwise, will not if the amniotic fluid is less. 
  • Option 5: Increased risk of hip dislocation in babies: This is correct

 

Educational Objective:

Etiology of Breech Presentation

  • Prematurity: MC cause
  • Factor preventing spontaneous version: Twins, Oligohydramnios, congenital malformation of uterus such as septate or bicornuate uterus, short cord.
  • Favorable adaptation: Hydrocephalus: Placenta previa; Contracted pelvis and Cornu-fundal attachment of the placenta.
  • Undue mobility of fetus: Hydramnios and Multiparas with lax abdomen.
  • Fetal abnormalities: Trisomy 13, 18, 21; Anencephaly and myotonic dystrophy due to alteration of fetal muscular tone and mobility.
  • Additionally, 6% of breech presentations are found to have congenital malformation, include congenital hip dislocation, hydrocephalus, anencephalous, familial dysautonomia, spina bifida, meningomyelocele, and chromosomal trisomy 13, 18, and 21, Thus, those conditions that alter fetal muscular tone and mobility increase the likelihood of breech presentation.

 

Ref: Page no 323  JB Sharma Textbook of Obstetrics 3rd edition

choices.text: 1,2,3,4
3,4,5
3,4
1,3,4,5

questions.text: In assisted breech delivery, after coming head can be delivered by which of the following?
questions.solution:
Ans.  D. 1,3,4,5

Arrest of after Coming Head (Difficulty with after- coming head): Managed

  • Spontaneous delivery can occur: Especially in small fetuses
  • Burns-Marshall method
  • Modified Mauriceau-Smellie-Veit technique
  • Forceps application (Piper forceps)
  • Bracht maneuver
  •  Wigand-Martin maneuver
  •  Prague maneuver
  • Duhrssen’s incision
  •  Craniotomy

Burns marshall, Mauriceau smellie veit and piper forceps are the most common techniques to deliver the after coming head.
 

Pinard maneuver is to help deliver the legs especially in a frank breech or in a total breech extraction (Pressure on the popliteal fossa)

Educational Objective:

Arrest of after Coming Head (Difficulty with after- coming head): Managed

  • Spontaneous delivery can occur: Especially in small fetuses
  • Burns-Marshall method
  • Modified Mauriceau-Smellie-Veit technique
  • Forceps application (Piper forceps)
  • Bracht maneuver
  •  Wigand-Martin maneuver
  •  Prague maneuver
  • Duhrssen’s incision
  •  Craniotomy

 

Ref: Page no 329  JB Sharma Textbook of Obstetrics 3rd edition

choices.text: The incidence of cord prolapse in breech presentation is 1%
Incidence of breech at 28 weeks is 25%
ECV is successful in 60% of patients.
The most common position in breech is left sacro-anterior

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding breech is false?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. The most common position in breech is left sacro-anterior

Let's Discuss all the Options

  • Option A: The incidence of cord prolapse in breech presentation is 1%: This is Correct: The overall incidence of cord prolapse ranges from 0.1-0.6%. In the case of breech presentation, the incidence is higher at 1% and is highest in footling breech (5%).
  • Option B: Incidence of breech at 28 weeks is 25%: This is correct. The incidence of breech presentation decreases from about 20% at 28 weeks of gestation to 3-4% at term, as most babies turn spontaneously to the cephalic presentation.
  • Option C: ECV is successful in 60% of patients: Success rates of ECV is about 60% and it reduces the incidence of breech presentation from 3% to 1-1.5%.
  • Option D: The most common position in breech is left sacro-anterior. This is Incorrect. The most common type of breech is Right sacro anterior

Educational Objective: 

The most common type of breech is Right sacro anterior

 

Ref: Page no 326, JB Sharma Textbook of Obstetrics 3rd edition

choices.text: Give a liberal episiotomy
Do not do any manipulation till the umbilicus is born
The arms are delivered once the nape of the neck is seen
Using Piper forceps to deliver the head reduces the risk of intracranial hemorrhage

questions.text: You are conducting an assisted breech delivery of a primigravida who presented in active labor at 38 weeks. Which of the following will you NOT do?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. The arms are delivered once the nape of the neck is seen

  • Remember that the arms are delivered once the lower body of the scapula is seen.
  • All the other options are correct.

Educational Objective:

Conduct of an Assisted breech delivery:

  • Bring patient to edge of table once breech is seen to climb the perineum
  • Liberal medio-lateral episiotomy
  • Ask the woman to bear down
  • Do not manipulate till the umbilicus
  • Keep back anterior
  • If legs extended (frank breech), they can be delivered by pressure on popliteal fossa
  • Wrap the fetus in a warm towel
  • Deliver the arms once lower body of scapula is seen
  • Delivery of after coming head: Once nape of neck is seen: Supra pubic pressure applied to keep the head flexed and deliver by
    • Burns Marshall Technique
    • Mauriceau-Smellie-Veit technique
    • Piper forceps
      • Reduces incidence of fetal intracranial hemorrhage (prevents sudden compression/ decompression of fetal head)
      • Promotes flexion of the head
      • Avoids cervical spine injuries (traction is on the head not the neck)

 

 

Ref: Page no 330, JB Sharma Textbook of Obstetrics 3rd edition.

choices.text: Induction of labor
Cesarean section
Non-Stress Test
External cephalic version

questions.text: A 32 yr primigravida at 38 weeks presents to the OPD. Her BP is 140/90 mmHg and repeat BP after 30 mins is 150/100mmHg. Abdominal exam reveals a term uterus with fetus in breech presentation with FHR 140 bpm. What is the next best step?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Cesarean section.

  • This patient has high BP (preeclampsia or gestational HTN as nothing else is mentioned) but either way, delivery has to be planned as she has crossed 37 weeks. This is called a complicated breech i.e. breech with any other obstetric complication. Complicated breech is a direct indication for cesarean section. 
  • The mode of delivery is to be by cesarean section as this is a complicated breech (Any breech with an associated complication) is called complicated breech.

Other options

  • Option A: Induction of labor: This is not preferred as this is a complicated breech. Assisted breech delivery is best avoided. 
  • Option C: NST: Although antepartum and intrapartum fetal surveillance are required it is not the "next best step" for this patient
  • Option D: ECV: ECV is done at 36-37 weeks and is done when there is no other associated complication.

 

Educational Objective:

  • Complicated breech is a direct indication for elective cesarean section

 

Ref: Page no 329  JB Sharma Textbook of Obstetrics 3rd edition

choices.text: External cephalic version
Ultrasound
Cesarean section at 37 weeks
Review after 1 week

questions.text: You are examining a 32yr primigravida who is 36 weeks pregnant. On the fundal grip, a hard ballotable structure is felt. What is the next best step?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Ultrasound

  • The fundal grip is suggestive of the head and hence this could be breech presentation
  • The next best step would be to confirm the presentation and also to look for causes of breech. This is best done by an ultrasound where we can see
    • Presentation
    • Any fetal anomaly
    • Amniotic fluid quantity (AFI)
    • Placental localization (rule out placenta previa)
    • Look for hyperextended head
    • Estimated fetal weight
  • All these will help us decide the next plan of management i.e. is she favorable for external cephalic version or a cesarean section should be planned at term.
  • The patient also needs to be reviewed after 1 week but the presentation is unlikely to change and hence the next best answer is an ultrasound

Educational Objective:

Role of ultrasound in breech:

  • To confirm the presentation
  • Any fetal anomaly
  • Amniotic fluid quantity (AFI)
  • Placental localization (rule out placenta previa)
  • Look for hyperextended head
  • Estimated fetal weight

Ref: Page no 329  JB Sharma Textbook of Obstetrics 3rd edition

choices.text: Mauriceau smellie veit
Lovset
Burn Marshall
Prague

questions.text: Identify the following maneuver:
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Lovset

  • This is Lovset maneuver.
  • IT is a maneuver used in assisted breech delivery to deliver the arms, especially if the arms are above the head (nuchal arms)
  • Holding the baby in a femoro-pelvic grip, the trunk is rotated so that the shoulders occupy the AP diameter of the pelvic inlet.
  • Usually the post shoulder is delivered 1st with the ant shoulder hinging below the pubic symphysis.
  • This is followed by delivery of the ant shoulder.

Educational Objective:

 

This is the Lovset maneuver which is useful in delivering nuchal arms when conducting an assisted breech delivery

 

Ref: Page no 329, JB Sharma Textbook of Obstetrics 3rd edition

choices.text: Wigand Martin
Mauriceau Smellie Veit
Burn Marshall
Bracht maneuver

questions.text: A resident is demonstrating techniques of delivery of the after coming head in breech delivery in the skills lab. You reach late and are witnessing the following maneuver. What is this maneuver?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Burn Marshall

  • This is the Burn Marshall method
  • Most commonly used method
  • Supra pubic pressure exerted
  • The obstetrician takes the infant's legs in the right hand placing the middle finger between the 2 ankles.
  • Lift the infant towards the maternal abdomen in an arc-like movement.

Other methods:

Mauriceau Smellie Veit:

  • Another method of delivery
  • Fingers of the left forearm is placed under the fetal body
  • The index finger and middle finger of this hand are applied over the maxilla (malar bones) to flex the head.
  • The other (right hand) is placed on the back with the finger pushing the occiput to promote flexion

This is the Bracht Maneuver

Wigand Martin maneuver: Is another maneuver to deliver the aftercoming head in breech

 

 

Ref: Page no 330, JB Sharma Textbook of Obstetrics, 3rd edition

choices.text: Frank breech
Footling breech
Complete breech
Incomplete breech

questions.text: A 33-year-old primi in labor is found to have a breech presentation. What is the most common type of breech presentation in which the baby's buttocks present first?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Frank breech

 

Explanation: In a frank breech (70%) presentation, the baby's buttocks present first, and the knees are extended. This is the most common type of breech presentation.

 

  • Extended Breech (Frank breech): Flexion at hip joint, Extension at knee joint (60- 70%)
  • Flexed Breech (Complete breech): Flexion at hip joint, flexion at knee joint (around 10%)
  • Footling breech: Extension at hip and knee joint (around 25%)
  • Kneeling breech: Extension at hip joint, flexion at knee joint 

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Ref: Dutta’s textbook of obstetrics 8th edition Pg 434

choices.text: Complete breech
Footling breech
Incomplete breech
Frank breech

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman is in labor with a breech presentation. What is the term used to describe the position where the baby's knees are extended, and the feet are near the head in this type of breech presentation?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Frank breech

Explanation: In a frank breech presentation, the baby's buttocks present first, and the knees are extended with the feet near the head.

  • Extended Breech (Frank breech): Flexion at hip joint, Extension at knee joint
  • Flexed Breech (Complete breech): Flexion at hip joint, flexion at knee joint
  • Footling breech: Extension at hip and knee joint
  • Kneeling breech: Extension at hip joint, flexion at knee joint 

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Ref: Dutta’s textbook of obstetrics 8th edition Pg 434

choices.text: Increased risk of umbilical cord prolapse
Increased risk of shoulder dystocia
Higher incidence of breech entrapment
Lower chance of successful forceps delivery

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman in labor presents with a footling breech presentation. What is a potential concern with a footling breech presentation that can make it less suitable for vaginal delivery?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Increased risk of umbilical cord prolapse

 

Explanation:

  • In a footling breech, because the presenting part does not completely occlude the cervix as a head would, there is more space for the umbilical cord to slip past and prolapse, which can lead to cord compression and compromised fetal blood flow. This is one of the main concerns with footling breech presentations.

Other options:

  • Shoulder dystocia is a specific complication of vaginal delivery where the baby's head is delivered but the shoulders become stuck inside the mother's pelvis. This is more commonly associated with cephalic (head-first) presentations, especially with macrosomic (large) babies, babies of diabetic mothers, and is not a primary concern with a breech delivery.
  • While there can be a risk of entrapment of the fetal head in a breech delivery, this is not specifically a higher risk in a footling breech compared to other types of breech. The main concern with a footling breech is the potential for cord prolapse and the difficulty in delivering the after-coming head because it must pass through the birth canal last and is large.
  • Forceps are typically used to assist the delivery of the head in cephalic presentations, and they are not commonly used in breech deliveries. Though they may be used for aftercoming head.

Educational Objective:

  • The highest incidence of cord prolapse is in transverse lie followed by footling breech

 

 

Ref: Dutta’s textbook of obstetrics 8th edition Pg 460
